New York, NY 7/10/2012 2 photos Real hefty burger to enjoy with outdoor seating. Note: 4.5 stars
First time having Shake Shack, yes indeed, a NY native and a Shake Shack virgin for so long?! Well, with this amount of time, there's plenty of hype heard about the magnificence that are the almighty Shake Shack burgers. Got to the park stand by 11:20a and already there's a line. So heads up for those who think lunch hour doesn't start at 11a-ish. Waited about 20 minutes and got my order very smoothly. Even with such crowds and rush of orders, the cashier was quick and friendly. Next, waiting for the food took a little over 10 minutes due to the high volume rush. Note, some corporate workers may have a sheet of orders to bag. One sure did today, got an excel sheet with names, numbers, and what have you to order. With the condiment stand off to the left of the food pick up spot, I prepped up the napkins, straws, and ketchup revving to go. Once the little alert remote vibrated, time to pick up the food. The food received was very delicious to look at and so comfortably warm. Again, the worker that dispersed the orders was friendly too. I got the shack stack - cheeseburger with a portobello and lettuce tomato, shack burger - cheese, lettuce and tomato, arnold palmer - lemonade/iced tea mix, and a regular non-sweetened iced tea. The shack burger looked like any regular burger, but much prettier. Better organized and displayed. I ate the Shack stack and it was good. Extra cheesy and smooth with the Shake Shack sauce. BUT, with so much hype heard about Shake Shack, this burger wasn't the greatest thing in the burger universe though it is one of the saltiest in aftertaste. Perhaps I should've gotten a different one, definitely willing to partake Shake Shack again. The drinks were nothing special. Regular unsweetened iced tea, sugar is at the condiment stand. The arnold palmer mix wasn't too pleasant at first, but it plateaued to an okay taste after the 2nd sip - especially helpful with such a salty Shack stack.
Overall, definitely a spot to grab a burger for lunch. Don't know how I forgot to try their fries - so irregular to not have a side with a burger. Well, definitely a next time and looking forward to chugging down a shake and a different burger. Very good, but not great, yet worth a try - 4.5 stars!

Austin, TX 7/10/2012 Shake Shack has all the components of a cult burger revolution: exciting, yet convenient location--Madison Square Park; outrageous line length, often boasting an assortment of odd characters, whether in front or behind; and a "special sauce." Aside from these few aspects, they do have shakes. And fries. Moving on.
The secret sauce is more tart than the standard "Thousand Island" sorts of cryptic spreads for an American staple such as the iconic hamburger. They are keeping it straightforward with Cheddar, though. To round it all out, the bun is extremely soft and buttery. Our meat was juicy and offered a touch of juiciness.
On the whole, I figured the burger was not anything super unique, but it is certainly worth the wait. Now, as I analyzed the burger as an entity, I found that it was indeed above par, meaning superior to fast food, but for the experience, you pretty much can't beat a meat and bun combination from Shake Shack.
No one is gonna read this review, but I wanted to put my two cents out there. Unfortunately, it has lost its "local" feel, with it being spread around town nowadays, but you honestly won't get more of a true New York burger experience unless you get to this specific location, the original.
Oh, it was a little odd seeing a woman assisting her small boys in peeing into a bag right next to the Shack Shack line. Perhaps she reminded them to "shake." I found it to be pretty unappetizing. Fortunately, I had already downed my burger.

Berkeley, CA 7/8/2012 Went here with a friend of mine on his recommendation and got the Shack Stack and a "Black and White" (chocolate/vanilla) milkshake.
The Shack Stack is nominally just a normal burger with a cheese-stuffed deep-fried mushroom in the middle. However, the whole, in this case, is better than the sum of its parts. The patty is juicy but doesn't overwhelm the rest of the burger. The mushroom provided both a crispy (fried outside) and creamy (melted cheese in the middle) texture, and the rather-heavy taste of the patty and mushroom is complemented by fresh lettuce and tomatoes. A perfectly balanced burger with a nice little twist.
But the best part of the meal is the milkshake. It tasted like a dipped ice cream bar meets a blender (in a good way); chocolate and vanilla blends together in an indescribable way. So I won't attempt to do so and encourage you to try for yourself! :)

Newark, NJ 7/2/2012 Quick! Get to Madison Square Park before Comandante Bloomberg criminalizes the deep fryer!!!
So the posted pictures aren't very helpful. Imagine a sandwich sized brown paper bag. Two thirds of the bag are soaked through with grease. You have to carry it from underneath lest the bottom fall out. You are running east to get to your apartment because the hot oil is burning your carrying hand. With your other hand, you are stuffing cheese-slathered fries down your gullet. You're there! Unfortunately, you have to dry one of your hands down the front of your shirt to avoid ruining your new slacks while reaching for your keys. Do you wipe the cheese-covered hand relegating your shirt to bro-cations and mom's house? Or do you attempt switching the bag to the other hand at the risk of dropping your dinner all over the sidewalk?
This is the type of moral dilemma that one runs the risk of encountering after a visit to the Shake Shack. However, this Morton's Fork is not the fork you'll need to tackle SS. The shakes are thick. There's soft serve out there that isn't as dense. The Shroom Burger is what you would get if a stuffed mushroom and a Wisconsin mozzarella stick procreated on a bed of hot beef. Round out your meal with cheese fries if you haven't had enough dairy already.
The tables are always filled, get it to go; the lines are ridiculous, but it's worth the wait.

Cerritos, CA 6/29/2012 1 Check-in Here Am I allowed to review this place even though I'm not from New York? When my friends and I first got to the famous Shake Shack location, I was really tempted to suggest to eat somewhere else because the line was ridiculously long. The humidity was doing nothing for my hair, and my feet were hurting from touring all day. But of course my friends who are residents of New York insisted that I try this place since I was only visiting for a short while. Also, I secretly really wanted to try this place after seeing Ginnifer Goodwin and John Krasinski have their enlightening conversations here in 'Something Borrowed'.
After waiting for about half an hour and starving, I was rather alarmed at how small the burgers were when I picked them up from the window -- I mean, my burger was gone after about 10 bites. Maybe I was just famished from walking all over New York, but the burger was gone rather quickly. Aside from the fact that it was too small for my taste (next time I'll order 2), the burger was quite juicy and flavorful, and I really enjoyed the ambiance of Madison Square Park. Also, we got lucky as there was a live band that provided good music and entertainment as we ate our kids meal-sized burgers.
As a born and bred Californian, In-N-Out takes cake or should I say, cheeseburger, when it comes to delicious burgers. But I am glad to say that at least I've tried Shake Shack during my visit to New York, and I did get cute pictures of the place. Instagram!

Beverly Hills New South Wales Australia 6/20/2012 1 photo My wife and I came here for dinner on the first night we arrived in NYC after what was close to a 24 hour flight from Australia. Admittedly i would have eaten anything but after reading and hear so much about Shack Shack I had to make it my first NYC food experience.
I wasn't disappointed.
I ordered a double shack burger with onion and I couldn't fault it. The meat was crisp and charred on the outside and pink and juicy in the middle.
Washed down with a Shack meister ale and i was in burger heaven.
The fries weren't the best but they were good enough.
The free wifi in madison square park was great. after 24 hours with no facebook i was getting a bit edgy
We returned for dinner again at about 9pm on a Friday night to see a MASSIVE line. I had read reviews and heard about the line and I thought everyone was being a bit over the top, but it gets long and it suxs. We were told it was about 50 minutes wait. We had tickets to a UCB show at 10pm so we jumped on the subway up to the 8th ave Shake Shack which had a much shorter line.
All in all it was an awesome burger. I still think about shake shack (and In-n-out) most days and burgers back in Australia just don't seem to cut it anymore.

History
Established in 2004
Shake Shack is a modern day"roadside burger stand"serving the most delicious burgers, hot dogs, frozen custard, beer and wine. Shake Shack was born from a hot dog cart in Madison Square Park (MSP) created by Union Square Hospitality Group to support the Madison Square Park Conservancy's first art installation"I Taxi."The cart was a success and lines formed daily, so it re-opened for an additional two summers in 2002 and 2003. In July 2004, Shake Shack officially opened. Shake Shack instantly became a beloved NYC institution with a cult following, and for years guests asked us when a Shack would open in their neighborhood.In October 2008, a second Shake Shack opened on the Upper West Side (UWS) of Manhattan. In April 2009, Shake Shack debuted its third location at Citi Field. Shack's mission is to preserve the culinary traditions of classic American burger stands.
